summary: A letter from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) to Judge Alison J. Nathan addressing concerns about Ghislaine Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn. It details her housing, access to amenities, meals, medical care, COVID-19 protocols, and legal access, asserting her treatment complies with BOP policies.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case (20 Cr. 330) and has judicial oversight, prompting her inquiry into Maxwell's detention conditions.
The BOP staff attorney is corresponding with the court to detail and defend the conditions of Maxwell's confinement as an inmate.

keyFacts: The Bureau of Prisons states Ghislaine Maxwell is housed separately from the general population at MDC Brooklyn due to her expressed safety concerns.
Maxwell has extensive daily access to common areas, recreation, legal calls, email, computers, and discovery material from 7:00 AM to 8:00 PM.
Her cell temperature is checked three times daily, and she is subjected to overnight wellness checks with flashlights and routine searches, including body scanners.
Despite COVID-19 cases at the facility, the BOP asserts Maxwell remains in good health, is not in contact with positive individuals, and staff on her unit are also isolated.
Maxwell's medical records indicate she weighs approximately 134 lbs. and she receives three meals daily in accordance with the BOP National Menu.
